brief_summary.textblock:
Seizures are a potential complication of surgical repair of intracranial aneurysms.  In
      order to prevent seizures, many surgeons administer prophylactic anti-epileptic medication
      during the intra-operative and post-operative period, however, such practice is not
      supported by clinical data.  Retrospective review found the incidence of postoperative
      seizures was higher in those who received anti-epileptics versus those who did not.  The
      goal is to examine the utility of levetiracetam (Keppra) for seizure prophylaxis in patients
      undergoing surgical repair of ruptured and unruptured intracranial aneurysms.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          1. Adult (≥18 years)

          2. Presence of  intracranial aneurysm (with or without rupture)

          3. Treating surgeon has recommended surgical repair of the aneurysm.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          1. History of seizures within last 10 years

          2. History of epilepsy

          3. History of prior stroke

          4. Currently prescribed medication with anti-epileptic activity
             (keppra,dilantin, tegretol, lamictal, topamax, etc.)

          5. Brain tumor

          6. Pregnant or nursing woman

          7. Known levetiracetam allergy

intervention.description: 500 mg intravenous dose during the operative case then 500 mg orally twice a day for a total of seven days

authority: United States: Food and Drug Administration

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
